simPRO Rest API
 v1.0

What is the simPRO API

Our RESTful API allows you to view, create or edit resources on any simPRO builds.

It uses oAuth2 to authenticate your application. This page describes how you can register your application, and also how to obtain, use and refresh oAuth2 access tokens.

After you have obtained an access token, you can start requesting resources using the API.

You can explore the features of the API via our documentation. The documentation lists all available endpoints and details the input and output of each one.

Software

We do not recommend using your browser to interact with the API. Use curl, Postman, Insomnia, your favourite REST client,
or any programming language which can make HTTP requests. GuzzleHttp is an excellent package if you are using PHP.

First things first

Before registering your application, you should determine which authentication method you wish to use. Different methods serve different types of applications.

Click here for a full overview of authentication methods.

Swagger / OpenAPI 2.0

Our RESTful API is designed with Swagger / OpenAPI 2.0 specification in mind, you can download our specification from here.

Grant types overview

There are five different methods of authenticating your application with our API. This page is intended to assist you with deciding which one is best suited to your application.

Most of these are based on oAuth2 which is an industry standard for authentication. See their website for more information.

Authorisation and implicit code grants

If your application is a website, and can redirect the client's browser to our server, then we suggest either Authorisation Code Grant or Implicit Code Grant.
Using either of these options, you implement a "Log in with your simPRO account" button which redirects the user to our system for logging in,
and then we will redirect the client's browser back to your system with an access code.

If your application has a secure database, such as a server-side web application, then we recommend Authorisation Code Grant. If your application has no secure database
(such as a single-page javascript-based application), then for security reasons we recommend Implicit Code Grant.

Resource owner credentials grant

Using resource owner credentials grant, the user will enter their simPRO username and password into your application. Your application will then relay these details to our system,
which will respond with an access token if successful.

Client credentials grant and API key

If your application does not log a particular user into the system, but rather has global access to the whole system, then use Client credentials grant or API key.

Client credentials grant is the more secure option since it uses oAuth2. Whereas API key is a single access token which never expires.

The next step

Now that you've decided which authentication method you wish to use, the next step is to register your application. Click here for instructions.

Registering your application

There are two ways to register your application:-

  • Engage directly with an individual simPRO client and work with their application administrator to allow your application to connect to their environment build. Use the Grant Types Overview to determine which integration method is appropriate for you and the client.
  • Engage directly with simPRO to have your application credentials added to all client deployments, this will include your application name as an API candidate in each simPRO client environment. This is Partner-level engagement.

To be included for Partner-level engagement, your application must meet certain criteria. Read more

If not engaging at the Partner level, before registering your application, please decide upon which authentication method you will use for your application by reading through the Grant types overview.

Contact the business whose simPRO build you wish to access. Ask someone with administrative privileges to add a new Rest API Application.

  • Click on System -> Setup
  • API should be near the bottom. If it is not available, then they may not be an administrator. Hover over it and click Applications.
  • Click Create Application
  • Company is your company name. Name is a sensible, unique name for the application you are registering.
  • If you are using authorisation or implicit code grant type, please provide them with a Redirect URI. After the user authorises your application, the code needs to be sent back to your system.
    • Eg. https://your.company.com/yourapp/oauth2redirect
  • Please also provide them with an email address for receiving your access details.
  • Select which grant type you wish to use.
  • Click Create
  • They then need to download the key file, and email it to you.

Time to authenticate

Now that you're registered, you can now authenticate your application with the API and begin making requests. Click here for instructions.

Partner Level Engagement

The benefits to you as a simPRO integration Partner are:

  • Your credentials would pre-exist in simPRO so your application can be easily enabled by a client by logging in to their simPRO build via your application to authorise access.
  • You do not need to perform the “register your application” steps.

To get started you will need to perform integration testing. To help with testing, we can provide a simPRO sandbox environment that can simulate a client build.

Create your own login credentials and use the sandbox environment for initial development.

Once you have completed your integration testing, you will need to demonstrate your application and we will confirm that the authorisation process, simPRO branding, and support for both single and Multi-company builds are as expected. We will then issue you a single set of credentials.

For all Partner level integration simPRO mandates the use of the Authorisation Code Grant method (using OAuth 2.0). Your single set of credentials would be provided to you by simPRO.These credentials would be recognised by each client build.

You would use these credentials to acquire an access token from each authorised client build.To acquire an access token, follow the guide in using these credentials each time. The client only needs to log in to simPRO via your application.

All simPRO client build URLs are formatted as <buildname>.simprosuite.com or <buildname>.simprocloud.com (simprosuite.com is the default). Your application would be expected to provide an authorisation login process that allows the client to enter their simPRO build name and would then direct them to their simPRO build URL to log in and authorise access for your application. You would send your credentials in this https request.

To get started with Partner-level engagement, please visit Become a simPRO Partner

How to authenticate

Once you have registered your application, you may now authenticate your application with the API, and start making requests.

The workflow for each authentication is different. Details are below:

  • Authorisation Code Grant
  • Resource Owner Credentials Grant
  • Implicit Grant
  • Client Credentials Grant
  • API Key

Authorisation code grant workflow

The key file you received will contain the Authentication URL, Redirect URL, Token URL, Client ID and Client Secret.

You will need to create a link on your webpage which says words to the effect of "Login with your simPRO account". This link will take the user to <Authentication URL>

There, the user will be prompted to enter their login details and asked whether they wish to authorise your application. After some time, our system will redirect the user back to your system.

This redirect will contain either a code or an error. If it is an error, it will be in the format:

<Redirect URL>?error=access_denied&error_description=The+user+denied+access+to+your+application&state=

The response indicating a successful authorisation will be in the format:

<Redirect URL>?code=fb4c99f1f439fc16e30ce475743965bf13a09b31&state=

Anything you specify in the "state" parameter will be echoed back to you. Use it to include extra data, such as the CSRF token. See https://auth0.com/docs/protocols/oauth2/oauth-state

You will need to exchange this code for an access token within 3 minutes. Do this by posting to the <Token URL> with the following json data:

{
  "grant_type": "authorization_code",
  "client_id": <client_id>,
  "client_secret": <client_secret>,
  "code": <From redirect url parameters>,
  "state": ""
}

{
  "access_token":"c82363eb05bc94857faafed0166239e00f03369f",
  "expires_in":3600,
  "token_type":"Bearer",
  "scope":null,
  "refresh_token":"6de678ea09eb98944bb7945605182c230aff3699"
}

simPRO does not use the scope parameter. Save the access token, type, and refresh tokens in your database. Ensure that this information is kept secret - not accessible publicly or by the user.

Now you have enough information to access the API. In each request, include the headers:

Authorization: Bearer <access_token>
Content-Type: application/json

Before or after the token expires, obtain a new access token without the user needing to login again by posting to <Token URL> with the json:

{
  "grant_type": "refresh_token",
  "client_id": <client_id>,
  "client_secret": <client_secret>,
  "refresh_token": <From previous response>,
  "state": ""
}

You will get a new access token and refresh token. The old tokens will no longer be usable.

Resource owner credentials grant workflow

The key file you received will contain the Token URL, Client ID and Client Secret.

Post to the <Token URL> with the following json data:

{
  "grant_type": "password",
  "client_id": <client_id>,
  "client_secret": <client_secret>,
  "username": <Entered by the user>,
  "password": <Entered by the user>
}

Should get a response similar to:

{
  "access_token": "6de88dc4a6da8552e60410b8281454c5db868897",
  "expires_in": 3600,
  "token_type": "Bearer",
  "scope": null,
  "refresh_token": "dd9339f2f8b7a4bf82ff7306a48439c9be0eacf1"
}

Scope is not used. The access_token and refresh_token should be stored in your application's local database.

Now you have enough information to access the API. In each request, include the headers:

Authorization: Bearer <access_token>
Content-Type: application/json

Before or after the token expires, obtain a new access token without the user needing to login again by posting to <Token URL> with the json:

{
  "grant_type": "refresh_token",
  "client_id": <client_id>,
  "client_secret": <client_secret>,
  "refresh_token": <refresh_token>
}

After requesting a refresh token, the response should look like:

{
  "access_token": "d6a6ac8f263e278ac2bde2e8731cc6304be3c916",
  "expires_in": 3600,
  "token_type": "Bearer",
  "scope": null,
  "refresh_token": "ef917c8816779371020872a3354da640b1ab832c"
}

You will get a new access token and refresh token. The old tokens will no longer be usable.
Please note that the refresh token will be expired in 14 days.

Implicit grant workflow

If your application does not have a secure database, then the email you receive will contain the Authentication URL, Redirect URL and Client ID.

You will need to create a link on your webpage which says words to the effect of "Login with your simPRO account". This link will take the user to <Authentication URL>

There, the user will be prompted to enter their login details and asked whether they wish to authorise your application. After some time, our system will redirect the user back to your system.

This redirect will contain either a code or an error. If it is an error, it will be in the format:

<Redirect URL>?error=access_denied&error_description=The+user+denied+access+to+your+application&state=

The response indicating a successful authorisation will be in the format:

<Redirect URL>#access_token=b0252f073b21665ee52850353a30358f49f52ac5&expires_in=3600&token_type=Bearer&state=

Please note that the access token is sent as a URL Fragment #access_token= and not as a query string parameter.
This is because implicit is designed for javascript clients, and done for security reasons.
Click here for more information.

Save the access token in local storage. The token will expire in the number of seconds specified in the "expire_in" parameter. After which, the client will need to log in again.

Now you have enough information to access the API. In each request, include the headers:

Authorization: Bearer <access_token>
Content-Type: application/json

Client credentials grant workflow

The key file you received will contain the Token URL, Client ID and Client Secret.

Post to the <Token URL> with the following json data:

{
  "grant_type": "client_credentials",
  "client_id": <client_id>,
  "client_secret": <client_secret>
}

Should get a response similar to:

{
  "access_token": "6de88dc4a6da8552e60410b8281454c5db868897",
  "expires_in": 3600,
  "token_type": "Bearer",
  "scope": null
}

Scope is not used. The access_token should be stored in your application's local database.

Now you have enough information to access the API. In each request, include the headers:

Authorization: Bearer <access_token>
Content-Type: application/json

Before or after the token expires, repeat the above to fetch a new access token. The old token will no longer be usable.

API key workflow

The key file you received will contain the access token. This should be stored in your application's local database.

In each request, include the headers:

Authorization: Bearer <access_token>
Content-Type: application/json

See some examples

See some examples of API usage by clicking here.

Example requests

Now that you're authenticated, you can start requesting resources using the API.
We will go over several examples of using the API. Don't forget to include the Authorization and Content-Type headers.
Each of these examples will use a relative url /api/ which should appear after the client's build as follows:

https://<client>.simprosuite.com/api/

By default, all the requests should include application/json in the header, e.g.:

Accept: application/json

If you require further assistance with making requests, please contact simPRO support.

List resources

Fetch a list of companies from the client's build:

GET /api/v1.0/companies/

The response should be similar to:

[
  {
    "ID": 0,
    "Name": "Company One"
  },
  {
    "ID": 1,
    "Name": "Company Two"
  }
]

Get resource

Make a subsequent request to get more detail about company with ID 0

GET /api/v1.0/companies/0

{
  "ID": 0,
  "Name": "Company One",
  "Phone": "07 1234 5678",
  "Fax": "",
  "Email": "person@example.com",
  "Address": {
    "Line1": "123 Fake Street",
    "Line2": "Sydney NSW 2000"
  }
}

Search resources

You can filter your listings by searching. Include your search terms as url parameters, and url encode them. For example:

GET /api/v1.0/companies/?Name=Company%20One

You can also do wildcard searching by including the percent operator (%25)

GET /api/v1.0/companies/?Name=Comp%25

Search in nested columns by specifying Column1.Column2:

GET /api/v1.0/companies/?Address.Line2=%25NSW%25

Search by multiple fields by specifying more than one url parameter:

GET /api/v1.0/companies/?Name=Company%20One&Address.Line2=%25NSW%25

Date types are in the format YYYY-MM-DD:

GET /api/v1.0/companies/0/jobs/?DateIssued=2018-05-29

We also support several operators. To find all companies with an ID greater than 5:

GET /api/v1.0/companies/?ID=gt(5)

The full list of operators are:

  • lt: Less than. lt(5), lt(2018-01-01)
  • le: Less than or equal to. le(5), le(2018-01-01)
  • gt: Greater than. gt(5), gt(2018-01-01)
  • ge: Greater than or equal to. ge(5), ge(2018-01-01)
  • ne: Not equal to. ne(), ne(5), ne(2018-01-01), ne(Archived)
  • between: Specify a range of values. between(1,10), between(2018-01-01,2018-12-31)
  • in: Specify a list of values. in(5.5,7.8,11.3), in(2015-01-03,2018-01-01,2018-12-18), in(Pending,Archived)
  • !in: Specify a list of values not required. !in(5.5,11.3), !in(2018-01-01,2018-12-18), !in(Pending,Archived)

Post resource

You can create new resources using the post method. The posted data is contained within with the json body.

POST /api/v1.0/companies/0/customers/individuals/
{
  "Title": "Mr",
  "GivenName": "John",
  "FamilyName": "Smith",
  "Phone": "07 1324 5687"
}

In the response, the Location header specifies the url of the created resource. In addition to this, the full resource is specified in the json body.
The Location is also broken down into Resource-Base-URI and Resource-ID, giving you these details separately to use however you wish.

201 Created
Content-Type: application/json;charset=utf-8
Resource-Base-URI: /api/v1.0/companies/0/customers/individuals/
Resource-ID: 1881
Location: /api/v1.0/companies/0/customers/individuals/1881
{
  "ID": 1881,
  "Title": "Mr",
  "GivenName": "John",
  "FamilyName": "Smith",
  "Phone": "07 1324 5687",
  "AltPhone": "",
  ...etc.
}

Patch resource

You can update a resource using the patch method. The fields you wish to update is contained within with the json body.

PATCH /api/v1.0/companies/0/customers/individuals/1881
{
  "GivenName": "Johnno"
}

The response will be 204 No Content, however a subsequent GET request will show the updated resource:

GET /api/v1.0/companies/0/customers/individuals/1881

{
  "ID": 1881,
  "Title": "Mr",
  "GivenName": "Johnno",
  "FamilyName": "Smith",
  "Phone": "07 1324 5687",
  "AltPhone": "",
  ...etc.
}

Delete resource

You can delete a resource using the delete method.

DELETE /api/v1.0/companies/0/customers/individuals/1881

Will return a 204 No Content if successful.

Options method

Use the options method to determine which methods are allowed on a resource.

OPTIONS /api/v1.0/companies/0/customers/individuals/

The response will contain the allowed methods in both a header and in the json.

Allow: SEARCH, POST, OPTIONS

{
  "allow": "SEARCH, POST, OPTIONS"
}

More information

Find more information about the features of the API in our Advanced Usage section.

Multi-company builds

Most simPRO builds are for a single company. The company id for single-company builds is 0, and therefore each route begins with /api/v1.0/companies/0

To see whether a build is for single or multi company, check the info handler. You can see in this example that MultiCompany is false.

GET /api/v1.0/info/

{
  "Version": "18.2.6.0.3.2",
  "Country": "Australia",
  "MaintenancePlanner": true,
  "MultiCompany": false,
  "SharedCatalog": true,
  "SharedStock": true,
  "SharedClients": true,
  "SharedSetup": true,
  "SharedDefaults": true,
  "SharedAccountsIntegration": true
}

To see the list of companies, check the companies handler.

GET /api/v1.0/companies/

[
  {
    "ID": 0,
    "Name": "Company Name"
  }
]

If there is more than one company, then you will need to select which company to use when making a request.
For example, if you wish to view customers for the company with ID 1, then your request will be:

GET /api/v1.0/companies/1/customers/

Pagination

When you retrieve a listing, only the first 30 results are shown. There are headers which give you information about pagination.

GET /api/v1.0/companies/0/jobs/

Result-Total: 10666
Result-Pages: 356
Result-Count: 30

The Result-Pages header tells you how many pages there are. The Result-Total header tells you how many records there are in total.
You can view other pages using the query string parameter page.

GET /api/v1.0/companies/0/jobs/?page=2

You can also specify the number of results per page you wish to see, up to a maximum of 250.
In this example, the number of pages reduces to 43 because there are 250 results per page.

GET /api/v1.0/companies/0/jobs/?pageSize=250&page=2

Result-Total    10666
Result-Pages    43
Result-Count    250

Understanding errors

If you request an invalid resource, or if you attempt to patch/post/put invalid data, the system will respond with an error.

GET /api/v1.0/companies/0/customers/individuals/345345345345

404 Not Found

{
  "errors": [
    {
      "path": null,
      "message": "Individual customer not found.",
      "value": null
    }
  ]
}

The path and value are used to help diagnose errors in the data you send.

POST /api/v1.0/companies/0/customers/individuals/

{
  "ID": 1885,
  "Title": 123,
  "GivenName": "Michael",
  "FamilyName": "Dickson",
  "Address": {
    "Address": "",
    "City": 123
  }
}

422 Unprocessable Entity

{
  "errors": [
    {
      "path": "/ID",
      "message": "This API Column does not allow POST requests.",
      "value": 1885
    },
    {
      "path": "/Title",
      "message": "Must be in { \"\", \"Mr\", \"Mrs\", \"Miss\", \"Ms\", \"Dr\", \"Sir\" }",
      "value": 123
    },
    {
      "path": "/Address/City",
      "message": "Must be a string",
      "value": 123
    }
  ]
}
  • The ID column cannot be posted to. The system determines the primary key of the resource, and it cannot be specified
  • Title has a restricted list of options
  • String fields cannot accept numerical types, but they can accept the string "123"

The path identifies which field, and each segment of the path is separated by forward slashes.
The value confirms to you what the system received which may help you diagnose the error.

Split routes

Some resources are fundamentally similar but have different fields. A good example is customers.
Company customers have a company name, but individual customers have title, first name and surname.
Each customer, regardless of its type, has a unique id.

Consider the following routes:

List all customers
/api/v1.0/customers/

List all company customers
/api/v1.0/customers/companies/

List all individual customers
/api/v1.0/customers/individuals/

Fetch data for company customer 151
/api/v1.0/customers/companies/151

Fetch data for individual customer 155
/api/v1.0/customers/individuals/155

To assist you with determining which route to use, the customer listing contains a field _href which guides you to the correct handler.

GET /api/v1.0/companies/0/customers/

[
  {
    "ID": 605,
    "_href": "/api/v1.0/companies/0/customers/companies/605",
    "CompanyName": "Company Customer One",
    "GivenName": "",
    "FamilyName": ""
  },
  {
    "ID": 1533,
    "_href": "/api/v1.0/companies/0/customers/individuals/1533",
    "CompanyName": "",
    "GivenName": "Individual",
    "FamilyName": "Customer One"
  }
]

Another way of determining the correct handler is to attempt to retrieve a customer's details without specifying a type,
and fetching the _href field from the error message.

GET /api/v1.0/companies/0/customers/1533

{
  "error": "Invalid resource URI. The correct URI is specified in _href and available from the resource listing.",
  "_href": "/api/v1.0/companies/0/customers/individuals/1533"
}

Post and patch multiple

If you have many resources to create or update, you can send these through in bulk.
Add /multiple/ to the end of a resource's base route and send through your data in an array.

POST /api/v1.0/companies/0/customers/individuals/multiple/

[
  {
    "GivenName": "Peter",
    "FamilyName": "Smith"
  },
  {
    "GivenName": "Michael",
    "FamilyName": "Dickson"
  }
]

Each item in the response json is a miniature response object with status, headers and body.
For performance reasons, we do not echo back the data in each body.

200 OK

[
  {
    "status": 201,
    "headers": {
      "Batch-ID": 0,
      "Resource-ID": 1882,
      "Location": "/api/v1.0/companies/0/customers/individuals/1882"
    },
    "body": null
  },
  {
    "status": 201,
    "headers": {
      "Batch-ID": 1,
      "Resource-ID": 1883,
      "Location": "/api/v1.0/companies/0/customers/individuals/1883"
    },
    "body": null
  }
]

The Batch-ID helps you identify which resource id belongs with which resource.
By default, it is the index of the array you specified, however you can specify it yourself.
This is useful if you have your own numerical key you wish to use to identify each item.

POST /api/v1.0/companies/0/customers/individuals/multiple/

[
  {
    "BatchID": 53,
    "GivenName": "Peter",
    "FamilyName": "Smith"
  },
  {
    "BatchID": 655,
    "GivenName": "Michael",
    "FamilyName": "Dickson"
  }
]

200 OK

[
  {
    "status": 201,
    "headers": {
      "Batch-ID": 53,
      "Resource-ID": 1884,
      "Location": "/api/v1.0/companies/0/customers/individuals/1884"
    },
    "body": null
  },
  {
    "status": 201,
    "headers": {
      "Batch-ID": 655,
      "Resource-ID": 1885,
      "Location": "/api/v1.0/companies/0/customers/individuals/1885"
    },
    "body": null
  }
]

To patch multiple, you need to include the resource's id in each item.

PATCH /api/v1.0/companies/0/customers/individuals/multiple/

[
  {
    "ID": 1884,
    "GivenName": "Peter",
    "FamilyName": "Smith"
  },
  {
    "ID": 1885,
    "GivenName": "Michael",
    "FamilyName": "Dickson"
  }
]

200 OK

[
  {
    "status": 204,
    "headers": {
      "Batch-ID": 0,
      "Resource-ID": 1884
    },
    "body": null
  },
  {
    "status": 204,
    "headers": {
      "Batch-ID": 1,
      "Resource-ID": 1885
    },
    "body": null
  }
]

Customise displayed columns

When listing or searching a resource, you can specify which columns you wish to see using the query string parameter columns.

GET /api/v1.0/companies/0/customers/individuals/?columns=ID,BillingAddress

[
  {
    "ID": 1885,
    "BillingAddress": {
      "Address": "123 Fake St",
      "City": "My City",
      "State": "STT",
      "PostalCode": "0001",
      "Country": "Australia"
    }
  },
  {
    "ID": 1884,
    "BillingAddress": {
      "Address": "",
      "City": "",
      "State": "",
      "PostalCode": "",
      "Country": "Australia"
    }
  }
]

This is handy if you have specific data you wish to see across all resources.

Replace resources using put

Very few of our handlers support the put operation. Unlike patch, in which you partially update a resource,
put completely replaces the existing resource with the one you specify. It essentially combines delete and post into one request.

A good example is if you're updating a job. If you have a list of labour items, you have a number of options regarding how to update them.
You can use the post operation to say "I wish to add these items to the list", or you can use the put operation to say "I wish to replace the existing items with these items".

Let's say your existing labour items look like:

GET /api/v1.0/companies/0/jobs/210787/sections/10922/costCenters/12006/labor/

[
  {
    "ID": 3680,
    "LaborType": {
      "ID": 1,
      "Name": "Labour RS"
    },
    "SellPrice": {
      "ExTax": 100,
      "IncTax": 110
    },
    "Total": {
      "Qty": 1,
      "Amount": {
        "ExTax": 100,
        "IncTax": 110
      }
    },
    "Claimed": null
  },
  {
    "ID": 3681,
    "LaborType": {
      "ID": 1,
      "Name": "Labour RS"
    },
    "SellPrice": {
      "ExTax": 100,
      "IncTax": 110
    },
    "Total": {
      "Qty": 1.5,
      "Amount": {
        "ExTax": 150,
        "IncTax": 165
      }
    },
    "Claimed": null
  }
]

Then you can replace them with different labour items by:

PUT /api/v1.0/companies/0/jobs/210787/sections/10922/costCenters/12006/labor/
[
  {
    "LaborType": 2,
    "LaborRate": 83,
    "LaborMarkup": 25,
    "Total": {
      "Qty": 1
    }
  }
]

The response will show that the existing items have been deleted and the new items added.

[
  {
    "ID": 3682,
    "LaborType": {
      "ID": 2,
      "Name": "Labour After Hours"
    },
    "SellPrice": {
      "ExTax": 103.75,
      "IncTax": 114.125
    },
    "Total": {
      "Qty": 1,
      "Amount": {
        "ExTax": 103.75,
        "IncTax": 114.125
      }
    },
    "Claimed": null
  }
]

Merge, append and replace data

See the previous section regarding replacing data. In addition to this, you can merge and append data.

Consider if you have a labour item:

[
  {
    "ID": 3682,
    "LaborType": {
      "ID": 2,
      "Name": "Labour After Hours"
    },
    "Total": {
      "Qty": 1
    }
  }
]

And you wish to add more labour with the same type. There are two options: either increase the quantity of the existing item, or create a new item.

Creating a new item (appending) is the default option, and is done using the post method:

POST /api/v1.0/companies/0/jobs/210787/sections/10922/costCenters/12006/labor/
[
  {
    "LaborType": 2,
    "LaborRate": 83,
    "LaborMarkup": 25,
    "Total": {
      "Qty": 3
    }
  }
]

Will result in two items: The original item with 1 hour plus the new item with 3 hours:

[
  {
    "ID": 3682,
    "LaborType": {
      "ID": 2,
      "Name": "Labour After Hours"
    },
    "Total": {
      "Qty": 1
    }
  },
  {
    "ID": 3683,
    "LaborType": {
      "ID": 2,
      "Name": "Labour After Hours"
    },
    "Total": {
      "Qty": 3
    }
  }
]

Instead of appending, let's say we merged instead. This is also done using the post method, but with an extra header

POST /api/v1.0/companies/0/jobs/210787/sections/10922/costCenters/12006/labor/
Post-Mode: merge
[
  {
    "LaborType": 2,
    "LaborRate": 83,
    "LaborMarkup": 25,
    "Total": {
      "Qty": 3
    }
  }
]

Instead of creating a new record, it will instead increase the quantity of the existing record to 4.

[
  {
    "ID": 3682,
    "LaborType": {
      "ID": 2,
      "Name": "Labour After Hours"
    },
    "Total": {
      "Qty": 4
    }
  }
]

To summarise:

  • Replace existing records using the PUT method
  • Append new records using the POST method
  • Merge into existing records using the POST method with the header Post-Mode: merge

Display subresources

Some resources have subresources. For example, jobs contain sections which contain cost centres, etc.
You can fetch all of this data in one call using the query string parameter display=all.

GET /api/v1.0/companies/0/jobs/210787?display=all

{
  "ID": 210787,
  "Type": "Project",
  "Sections": [
    {
      "ID": 10922,
      "Name": "aa",
      "DisplayOrder": 1,
      "CostCenters": [
        {
          "ID": 12006,
          "CostCenter": {
            "ID": 3,
            "Name": "Bench "
          },
          "Total": {
            "ExTax": 218.29,
            "Tax": 21.83,
            "IncTax": 240.12
          },
          "Items": {
            "Labors": [
              {
                "ID": 3682,
                "LaborType": {
                  "ID": 2,
                  "Name": "After hours"
                },
                "SellPrice": {
                  "ExTax": 103.75,
                  "IncTax": 114.125
                },
                "Total": {
                  "Qty": 1,
                  "Amount": {
                    "ExTax": 103.75,
                    "IncTax": 114.125
                  }
                },
                "Claimed": null
              }
            ],
            "Catalogs": [],
            "Prebuilds": [],
            "ServiceFees": [],
            "OneOffs": []
          }
        }
      ]
    }
  ]
}

The response contains the sections, cost centres, labour items, catalog items, and all of the other data which is contained within the subresources.

Post subresources

In addition to displaying subresources, you can also post subresources.
This removes the need to make multiple requests to post one job, for example.

The following will create a project job with one section, one cost centre, and one labour item.

POST /api/v1.0/companies/0/jobs/

{
  "Type": "Project",
  "Sections": [
    {
      "Name": "aa",
      "DisplayOrder": 1,
      "CostCenters": [
        {
          "CostCenter": 3,
          "Items": {
            "Labors": [
              {
                "LaborType": 2,
                "LaborRate": 83,
                "LaborMarkup": 25,
                "Total": {
                  "Qty": 1
                }
              }
            ]
          }
        }
      ]
    }
  ]
}

When posting an array, the index of the array will form part of the path.

POST /api/v1.0/companies/0/jobs/

{
  "Type": "Project",
  "Sections": [
    {
      "Name": "aa",
      "DisplayOrder": 1
    },
    {
      "Name": "aa",
      "DisplayOrder": "Shouldn't be a string"
    }
  ]
}

422 Unprocessable Entity

{
  "errors": [
    {
      "path": "/Sections/1/DisplayOrder",
      "message": "Must be between 0 and 32767",
      "value": "Shouldn't be a string"
    }
  ]
}

That error says that DisplayOrder within Section 1 has an error. The value will also help you identify what is causing the error.

Fetch only modified resources

Most of the handlers support the If-Modified-Since header. Specify the date and time of the most recent request you made, and it will show only the data modified since that time.

You do not need to calculate the date yourself. Each response contains the header Date.

Date: Wed, 30 May 2018 12:00:00 GMT

You can simply copy this and send it as a header in your next request.

GET /api/v1.0/companies/0/jobs/
If-Modified-Since: Wed, 30 May 2018 12:00:00 GMT

200 OK

Date: Wed, 30 May 2018 14:52:52 GMT

Zipped resources

All of the attachment folder handlers support an additional accept header. Every other handler only supports application/json

GET /api/v1.0/companies/0/contractors/54/attachments/folders/3
Accept: application/zip

This will redirect the client to a content disposition page for the zipped folder.

Attachments / Files

All of the attachment handlers support a /view/ route for accessing the file directly:

GET /api/v1.0/companies/0/contractors/54/attachments/3/view/

In addition, the file can be retrieved in base64 format:

GET /api/v1.0/companies/0/contractors/54/attachments/3?display=Base64

Web Hooks

Web hooks allow you to subscribe to events within simPRO. Instead of regularly polling to check if changes are made, you can be notified when they occur.

To understand how to create a subscription through the web interface, please check the documents below.

Alternatively if you wish to create a subscription the restful way, see: Webhook Subscriptions.

Create a Web Hook

Contact the business whose simPRO build you wish to access. Ask someone with administrative privileges to add a new webhook subscription.

  • Click on System -> Setup
  • API should be near the bottom. If it is not available, then they may not be an administrator. Hover over it and click Webhook Subscriptions.

  • Click Create Subscription.
  • Enter a name for this subscription.
  • Enter an email address which you may receive debugging information.
  • Secret is a random string of your choice, used to verify that the message you received came from simPRO.
  • Callback URL is what will be called each time an event occurs.
  • Select the events which you wish to subscribe to.

Test Subscription

After pressing save, click on Test Subscription to get an example payload.

Your URL will be called with the following data:

POST https://your.system.url/webhooks.php
{
  "ID": "test.updated",
  "build": "{BUILD_URL}",
  "description": "Test #1 has been updated.",
  "name": "Test",
  "action": "updated",
  "reference": {
    "testID": 1
  },
  "date_triggered": "2019-06-30T19:02:37-05:00"
}

Example Web Hook Payload

When an event occurs which you are subscribed to, your url will be called similar to the test subscription, but with actual data.

In the example below, company customer number 518 which belongs to company 0 has been updated.
The reference contains the raw parameter data which will allow you to fetch further information via the API.

POST https://your.system.url/webhooks.php
{
  "ID":"company.customer.updated",
  "build":"{BUILD_URL}",
  "description":"Company customer #518 has been updated.",
  "name":"Company customer",
  "action":"updated",
  "reference":{
    "companyID":0,
    "customerID":518,
    "companyCustomerID":518
  },
  "date_triggered":"2019-06-28T16:35:12+10:00"
}

Message Verification

When you receive a web hook message, you can verify that it was sent by simPRO. Recall that when setting up your
subscription, you entered your own random string into the Secret field.

In each message, the header X-Response-Signature contains a hash of the request body, calculated using an SHA1 HMAC hexdigest.

For security reasons, we recommend verifying it using a constant-time string comparison.

//From the subscription setup screen.
$secret = 'somerandomstring';

//hash_equals performs a constant-time string comparison.
if (!hash_equals($headers['X-Response-Signature'], hash_hmac('sha1', $requestBody, $secret))) {
    throw new \Exception('Hashes do not match');
}

Plant and Equipment

Plant items are equipment, such as tools, devices or even vehicles, that your company uses to complete jobs and needs to keep track of.
To keep track of where plant items are being used on jobs, you can schedule them, or alternatively, check out a plant item to an employee.
Since you are not allowed to double-book plant items, you always know where your plant items are and which ones are still available.
You can schedule plant items in the same way as you schedule employees. You can also create teams with both employees and plant items to schedule them together.

For example, your accounts department might not necessarily require access to quotes or pre-builds, or you might wish to limit the value of quotes or purchase orders issued by a particular user or user group.

Accounting Categories

Tax Codes

Your taxation system will use many tax codes to ensure appropriate revenue is set aside according to your local tax authorities' requirements.

Combine Tax Codes

This is a sum of multiple tax codes, or members, including both single and component tax codes.

You can report on either the combined tax code, or on the single or component tax codes. Combined tax codes will automatically update when a single or component member tax code is updated. When using the accounting link, the sum total of a combined tax code is sent to your accounting package and divided into individual member tax codes upon receipt.

Component Tax Codes

This can only be used as part of a combined tax code and cannot be used on transactions by itself.

Single Tax Codes

The system has predefined trigger points, and as you perform certain actions - such as emailing a quote - you pass one of these trigger points, triggering a change in the quote's status code and color.

Customer Tags

Customer Profiles

Create customer profiles and assign them to customers so that you can easily identify the quality or maturity of your relationship with the customer.

Profiles, such as gold, silver or bronze, assist in evaluating the level of commitment or financial risk associated with your customers. This is useful for searching and reporting on specific customers.

In simPRO, a zone is a geographical area used to schedule efficiently and minimize travel time for technicians.

Asset Types

Customer assets are equipment installed at customer sites that your business services regularly. Use customer assets to store information such as make, model and serial numbers. You can also keep track of your installation and maintenance history including test readings.
Asset types are useful for understanding what qualifies as an asset for your business. For example, a single asset may be an entire security system, or one individual component in the system such as a camera.

Asset Type Custom Fields

This feature is only available in simPRO Enterprise.

Use custom fields store different types of information against an asset type for efficient asset management.

Asset Type Service Levels

This feature is only available with Maintenance Planner purchased and enabled

Failure Points

Use failure points as specific test points for each service level when performing maintenance on customer assets.

Recommendations

Setup recommendations with Failure Points so that you can choose what to do next if an asset fails a test.

Test Readings

To enable technicians to record an asset's test results, for example, electrical readings, pressure readings, temperatures etc, accurately in the job card or in Connect, you need to create test readings in the asset type in simPRO. Test readings are then recorded as part of the asset history.

Service Levels

This feature is only available with Maintenance Planner purchased and enabled

Service levels determine the service and testing frequency for an asset. When you assign service levels to asset types, you can create failure points for the technician to select when testing to explain why the asset failed, and add recommendations to failure points to suggest how to rectify the failure.

When you add a new asset to a site, all service levels assigned to the asset type will be added to the asset. You can add or remove service levels as required by your contracts.

Currencies

If you sell or purchase goods and services in different currencies, you can set up multiple currencies in simPRO.

Info

Info handler gives you values of setting that are system wide.
